Answers.MP Summary: print resolved symbolic links or canonical file names
Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Get the actual file to which the symlink points
Top-3 Scripts:
so_7167424: #!/usr/bin/bash

for link in $(find /symdir -type l)
do
  loc="$(dirname "$link")"
  dir="$(readlink "$link")"
  mv "$dir" "$loc"
  rm "$link"
done

ul_604837: # includes complete left path
alias ls2l='if [[ $(diff <(ls "$PWD" | sed "s|.*|$(ls -d "$PWD/")&|g") <(ls -d "$(pwd -P)/"*) | wc -l) == "0" ]]; then ls -l; else paste -d " -> " <(ls "$PWD" | sed "s|.*|$(ls -d "$PWD/")&|g") /dev/null /dev/null /dev/null <(ls -d "$(pwd -P)/"*); fi'

# or 

alias  ls2='if [[ $(diff <(ls "$PWD" | sed "s|.*|$(ls -d "$PWD/")&|g") <(ls -d "$(pwd -P)/"*) | wc -l) == "0" ]]; then ls -l; else paste -d " -> " <(ls "$PWD") /dev/null /dev/null /dev/null <(ls -d "$(pwd -P)/"*); fi'

ul_74721: cd ~/path/to/dirs || exit 1
find /path/to/dirs -type d -printf %P\\0 | xargs -0 mkdir -p 
find /path/to/dirs -type f -print0 | 
  xargs -0 cp --symbolic-link --parents --target-directory=.
